results.snippet: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ANNIE LEIBOVITZ: LIFE THROUGH A LENS Ms. Leibovitz is arguably the most influential woman photographer in the country. But her private life is rarely exposed. In this documentary, which closes the 20th season of “American...
results.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) ANNIE LEIBOVITZ: LIFE THROUGH A LENS -- Ms. Leibovitz is arguably the most influential woman photographer in the country. But her private life is rarely exposed. In this documentary, which closes the 20th season of ''American Masters,'' Ms. Leibovitz (above, in her studio in 2003) shares her artistic process with her younger sister, the filmmaker Barbara Leibovitz, as she travels from her Manhattan studio to her idyllic farm in upstate New York, and through countless photo shoots and the creation of her latest retrospective book, while trying to balance career and motherhood. 8 P.M. (11) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK -- Osmosis, anyone? Eight physically glowing but intellectually dim women are paired with eight brainy but socially stunted men, with each presumably passing along some of their, um, finer attributes to the other. Oh, but it's difficult. 8 P.M. (13, 49) WIRED SCIENCE -- Wired, the science and technology magazine, translates its print content for television in this special, one of three pilots under consideration for development by PBS as a science series. Up for examination: meteorite hunters, viruses in Yellowstone National Park, and Neemo, NASA's extreme astronaut training facility. 9 P.M. (ABC) THE KNIGHTS OF PROSPERITY -- They've never even shoplifted a candy bar. But tired of being stuck in dead-end jobs that won't pay for a bottle of premium booze, this new-age Robin Hood (Donal Logue, right) and his Merry Men (one of whom is a woman) decide to finance their heart-felt dreams by plotting a heist of the super-swanky Central Park West apartment of no less than Mick Jagger. Yeah, they'll be giving to the poor: themselves. 9:30 P.M. (ABC) IN CASE OF EMERGENCY -- Enjoy the freefall: a group of former high school classmates (David Arquette, Jonathan Silverman, Greg Germann and Kelly Hu) find themselves reunited at a Los Angeles hospital when life starts taking its toll in this new sitcom. The doctor (Lori Loughlin) is a looker. 10 P.M. (ESPN) ALI'S 65 -- Muhammad Ali turns 65 on Jan. 17. This hourlong special presents 65 things -- facts, anecdotes, photographs and trivia -- that everyone should know about the heavyweight boxing champion (above, at a news conference in Atlanta in 1970) who liked to call himself ''the greatest of all time.'' And who are we to disagree? KATHRYN SHATTUCK

results.abstract: One of the enduring truths of Washington is that for as much as everyone rails against the place - even runs against "same old Washington" - few people ever leave.
results.snippet: One of the enduring truths of Washington is that for as much as everyone rails against the place - even runs against "same old Washington" - few people ever leave.

results.abstract: Momofuku Ando, founder of Nissin Food Products Co and inventor of preflavored dried ramen noodles, dies at age 96; photo (M)

headline.main: Momofuku Ando, 96, Dies; Invented Instant Ramen

results.snippet: Momofuku Ando’s invention was the delight of dormitory students and other kitchen-resistant customers worldwide.
results.lead_paragraph: Momofuku Ando, who -- to the delight of dormitory students and other kitchen-resistant customers worldwide -- invented those small packets of preflavored dried noodles that require just a three-minute boil, died Friday at a hospital in Osaka, Japan. Mr. Ando, the founder of the Nissin Food Products Company, was 96. The cause was heart failure, said Larry Lampel, the company's senior resources manager at its American headquarters in Gardena, Calif.

results.snippet: MOON PLANE. Written and illustrated by Peter McCarty. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 6) A silver plane flying overhead becomes a flight of fancy for a little boy standing in a field. “He wonders what it would be like to be on that flight. ... To travel...
results.lead_paragraph: MOON PLANE. Written and illustrated by Peter McCarty. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 6) A silver plane flying overhead becomes a flight of fancy for a little boy standing in a field. ''He wonders what it would be like to be on that flight. ... To travel farther than a boat sailing on the ocean.'' McCarty's ghostly gray pencil suggests the fog of a dream, as the plane lands on the moon and the boy bounces into the sky, suddenly an astronaut. Sure enough, the tale ends with the covers pulled up and a ''dream of airplanes flying high into the sky.'' A minimal story, but satisfying for those who love big machines, the moon and all things about flight. LIBRARY LION. By Michelle Knudsen. Illustrated by Kevin Hawkes. Candlewick. $15.99. (Ages 4 to 7) When a lion shows up at her library, the head librarian, Miss Merriweather -- who is ''very particular about rule breaking'' -- allows him to stay for story hour, then gradually, to make himself useful, dusting encyclopedias with his tail and licking envelopes for overdue notices. As long as he doesn't roar. But after a minor accident, the lion has to use his natural talent to help, even if it gets him in trouble. Fans of ''Danny and the Dinosaur'' should especially like this story, which proves that every now and then you have to break the rules. IF IT WEREN'T FOR YOU. By Charlotte Zolotow. Illustrated by G. Brian Karas. HarperCollins. $15.99. (Ages 3 to 8) An uncommonly honest look at sibling rivalry, evoking just how superfluous a younger sibling can seem to the firstborn. Though Karas's playful drawings lighten things up, Zolotow's text (originally published in 1966) is stern: ''If it weren't for you, I'd be the only child and I'd get all the presents. I could have the whole last slice of cake and the biggest piece of candy in the box. . . . If it weren't for you, I could have a room of my own.'' The older sister, an aggrieved-looking 9- or 10-year-old, can think of only one bright spot: ''I'd have to be alone with the grown-ups if it weren't for you.'' Still a good book for an older brother or sister who needs an understanding ear, though it may suggest grievances he or she had never even thought of. WELCOME, PRECIOUS. By Nikki Grimes. Illustrated by Bryan Collier. Orchard/Scholastic. $16.99. (Ages 0 to 3) A celebration of enduring familial love with images of a rural landscape, a sky-blue room (a rainbow enters in 3-D) and two adoring parents and their new baby. Grimes's text is sweet and tactile (''Welcome to rain-swept earth and spiced cider on the wind''), while Collier's watercolor-and-collage illustrations are almost photographic in depicting a family portrait that is as endearing as it is joyful. MS. RUBINSTEIN'S BEAUTY. Written and illustrated by Pep Montserrat. Sterling. $14.95. (Ages 5 and up) ''Ms. Rubinstein is a beautiful woman. But nobody knows it. Ms. Rubinstein has very beautiful eyes. But nobody sees them'' -- because Ms. Rubinstein is the Bearded Lady at the circus. On her day off she sits lonely on a park bench feeding the pigeons, her pretty hands moving ''harmoniously and delicately.'' Only Mr. Pavlov, from another visiting circus -- he seems to have a striped trunk -- can see her for who she truly is, leading to a charming lesson in looking beneath surfaces. Montserrat's stark black, red and white illustrations and witty text make for a simple but entertaining fable. MONDAY. Written and illustrated by Anne Herbauts. Enchanted Lion Books. $16.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A picture book that makes mysterious poetry out of the days of the week and seasons of the year. ''I am Spring. I am green, I abound. Into the wind I put its rustling sound,'' says an animated cloud. Most young readers probably won't make heads or tails of the surreal setting, in which Lester Day and Tom Morrow wait in vain at their grand piano for Monday to appear (he's blank with snow in the background -- the only clue being the stippled page), but they may find the moody, beautifully composed illustrations mesmerizing. Julie Just

results.abstract: Game Theory column reviews Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Justice for All, developed and published by Capcom for Nintendo DS; game costs $29.99; also reviews Warioware: Smooth Moves, developed by Intelligent Systems and published by Nintendo for its Wii gaming system; game costs $49.99; photos (M)

headline.main: Rough (but Silly) Justice and Striking (Also Silly) Moves

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: PHOENIX WRIGHT: ACE ATTORNEY JUSTICE FOR ALL (VIDEO GAME)

results.snippet: Invoking "the quiet dignity of a circus clown in the midst of a thunderstorm."
results.lead_paragraph: When the judge in a murder case pronounces a defendant not guilty, I doubt that confetti streams from the ceiling. I also suspect that the prosecutor is rarely a foul-tempered teenager who carries a whip and curtsies when she presents compelling evidence. But if trials were as entertaining in the real world as in Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney Justice for All, it might be worth jury duty just see it all firsthand. Phoenix Wright is the spiky-haired defense lawyer previously seen in Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney. In this sequel from CapCom for Nintendo DS, most of the rest of the cast also returns, including Phoenix's psychic sidekick, Maya, and the glum detective Dick Gumshoe.
